days.title: Day 1
instructions: Welcome to our program.
Today, we will try several different exercises.
I will guide you through each task as you try it.
It is very important that you follow my instructions carefully.
Don’t worry if you think you are not doing them perfectly; the most important thing is that you try your best.
If you feel any discomfort at during any of the tasks, you can choose to stop or skip.
We’ll try to complete all the exercises one after the other without interruption.
For any reason, if you need to stop, it is not a problem, raise your hand and the group will wait for you.
At any moment, if you are not feeling well, for example, if you are bothered by stress, sad memories, or unpleasant body sensations, stop if you think it is too much for you to handle.
These exercises are designed to help.
As your group leader, I am here to give you support.
Before we begin today, we’ll be sitting as a circle in this place and try to be without interruption for the next 90 minutes.
If visitors come by, they are welcome to watch if the group feels comfortable, but we ask that you don’t engage in conversations with them so that you can be focused on the tasks.
If you have a mobile phone, make sure you turn off so it is not a distraction during these exercises.
Is everybody ready?
Make your body comfortable where you are sitting.
Let’s get started.
days.notes: Group leaders: make sure children are placed with proper caregivers to not distract group concentration.

e1.title: Hand Warming
e1.objective: The goal of this exercise is to reduce stress of your participants using a guided visualization technique where they use the power of their imagination
steps: Ask participants to close their eyes, take a few deep breaths, and notice how their bodies feel by following the air travel inside their bodies.
When they are calm and relaxed, ask them to pay attention to their hands. Where is it resting? Is it warm or cold?
Give examples to help them imagine their hands getting warmer. (being under the sun, cooking, someone holding your hand, etc.).
Bring their attention back to their bodies and breath.
Count until 5 and ask them to slowly open their eyes.
e1.completion: Invite 2 participants who were able to experience hand warmth to share their experience with the group.

e2.title: Resonant Breathing
e2.objective: The goal of this exercise is to help your participants regulate heart beating pace by breathing in and out in the pace that you set for them for a period of 5 minutes.
steps: Instruct participants to sit comfortably. They can keep their eyes open or closed. They can choose to move their arms to the pace of the breath or rest them.
Follow the breath animation (or set a timer) for the following 5 minutes. (6’inhale/exhale breathing animation for 5’).
e2.completion: Invite 2 participants that enjoyed the task to share their positive experience with the group.

e3.title: Safe Place with Drums
e3.objective: Help participants feel safe through a guided visualization while tapping to the sound of drums (tapping helps stabilize the brain).
steps: Invite a group volunteer to tap gently and slowly to a drum or object that can generate a pleasing sound.
Demonstrate the tapping on shoulders or legs, always alternating between body sides and making sure it is very gentle.
Ask participants to close their eyes, take a few deep breaths, and notice how their bodies feel by following the air travel inside their bodies.
When they are calm and relaxed, ask them to imagine a safe place. Allow them time to stay at that safe place, pay attention to details, and how good they feel there.
Now ask them to invite a special guest to their safe place, someone they can trust and confide in. Ask them to take their guest around this place and enjoy their company.
Bring their attention back to their bodies and breath.
Count until 5 and ask them to slowly open their eyes.

e4.title: Stretch
steps: Ask participants to stand up for a very quick stretch. Demonstrate raising hands up in the air, shake arms and legs, move neck and hips.

e5.title: Safe Person
e5.objective: Help participants feel connected with a nurturing and caring figure, restore positive thinking about relationships
steps: Ask participants to close their eyes, take a few deep breaths, and notice how their bodies feel by following the air travel inside their bodies.

When they are calm and relaxed, still with their eyes closed ask participants to think of a “safe person” – someone they feel a special trusting connection with, it could be a friend, a parent, grandparent, husband, child, family member.
Ask participants to imagine this person with them right now.
Ask them to notice how this person makes them feel.
Ask them to pay attention to features in this person that makes them comfortable, the smile, voice, touch and stay with that good feeling.
Ask them to imagine sharing a special moment with them, going back to childhood, a moment that happened or a good one that they can create right now.
Ask them to pay attention back to their bodies and how good it feels in this person’s presence.
Bring their attention back to their breath.
Count until 5 and ask them to slowly open their eyes.
e5.completion: Invite 1 participant that enjoyed the task to share their positive experience with the group.

e6.title: Tap with the Drum During (+) Thought
e6.objective: Help participants regulate while tapping to the sound of drums (tapping helps stabilize the brain)
steps: Ask participants to think about a positive thought about themselves, someone else, or the world.
Ask those willing to share their positive thought with the group (keep it brief, go around but do not encourage long conversation). Never force someone to speak if they don’t wish to.
Invite a group volunteer to tap gently and slowly to a drum or object that can generate a pleasing sound.
Demonstrate the tapping on shoulders or legs, always alternating between body sides and making sure it is very gentle.
Ask participants to close their eyes, take a few deep breaths, and notice how their bodies feel by following the air travel inside their bodies.
When they are calm and relaxed, ask them to focus on the positive thought.
Bring their attention back to their bodies and breath.
Count until 5 and ask them to slowly open their eyes.
e6.completion: Invite 2 participants that enjoyed the task to share their positive experience with the group.

e7.title: Breath Work (Bubble)
e7.objective: The goal of this exercise is to help your participants feel safe by using imagination and breathing techniques. You will help them imagine they are building a bubble of protection around them every time they breathe in and breathe out.
steps: Ask participants to close their eyes, take a few deep breaths, and notice how their bodies feel by following the air travel inside their bodies.
Still with their eyes closed, ask participants to imagine a transparent bubble of protection growing around them as they breathe out as they sit inside of it, like blowing a balloon.
Continue guiding them to slowly take a deep breath in, and blow the bubble of protection for 5 breathing rounds.
Remind participants while they still have their eyes closed that this is a place where they feel protected, and nobody can go inside without invitation.
Ask whoever is ready to leave the bubble, to slowly open their eyes.

e8.title: Breath Work (VU Sound)
e8.objective: The goal of this exercise is to promote a sense of safety in participants by reproducing a vocal sound.
steps: Explain they will be making a sound when they breathe out.
Demonstrate the “VU” sound to participants.
Now ask them to do it along with you.
Repeat 10 times. You can make it a game to see who can sustain the VU sound longer.
e8.completion: Invite 2 participants that enjoyed the task to share their positive experience with the group.

e9.title: One Object
e9.objective: The goal of this exercise is to help participants train their minds to focus in the present moment by using a simple mindfulness skill (paying attention to one object in detail)
steps: Instruct participants to choose an object in their surrounding and bring back to the circle. It can be anything they can hold. For example, a piece of clothing, a rock, a leaf, piece of wood, a computer, their personal phone, etc. Assist participants that show difficulty choosing an object.
Ask participants to notice the weight of their object by passing it very gently from one hand to another.
Ask participants to notice the texture of their object. Is it smooth or rough? Does it roll on a surface?
Ask participants to notice the color of their object. Do they like the tone(s)? Is there a pattern printed on it? How about words?
Ask participants to notice if the object makes a sound.
Ask participants to take a final close look, and try to find something they still did not notice about this object.

e10.title: Guest House
e10.objective: This exercise is designed to help participants improve their skills of paying attention to the present moment (mindfulness) and feeling internal safety
steps: Ask participants to close their eyes, take a few deep breaths, and notice how their bodies feel by following the air travel inside their bodies.

When they are calm and relaxed, in a calm voice, read the “Guest House” poem to your group.

This being human is a guest house.
Every morning a new arrival.
A joy, a depression, a meanness,

Some momentary awareness come
As an unexpected visitor. 
Welcome and entertain them all! 

Even if they’re a crowd of sorrows,
who violently sweep your house
empty of its furniture,
still, treat each guest honorably.

He may be clearing you
Out for some new delight.

The dark thought, the shame, the malice,
meet them at the door laughing,
and invite them in.

Be grateful for whoever comes,
because each has been sent
as a guide from beyond.
Bring their attention back to their bodies and breath.
Count until 5 and ask them to slowly open their eyes.

e11.title: Jacobson
e11.objective: The goal of this exercise is to relax participants by conducting a full body scan
steps: Guide participants to sit very comfortably on a chair or on the floor.
Guide participants to pay attention to breath.
Guide participants to tense hands, then release tension.
Guide participants to tense fingers, then release tension.
Guide participants to tense forearms, then release tension.
Guide participants to tense upper arms, then release tension.
Guide participants to tense shoulders, then release tension.
Guide participants to tense upper back, then release tension.
Guide participants to tense lower legs, then release tension.
Guide participants to tense abdomen, then release tension.
Guide participants to tense Lower Back, then release tension.
Guide participants to tense Chest Area, then release tension.
Guide participants to tense shoulders (again) then release tension
Guide participants to tense Neck, then release tension.
Guide participants to tense Jaw, then release tension.
Guide participants to tense Eyes, then release tension.
Guide participants to tense all body and release all tension. Ask them to focus on Sensations of relaxation.
e11.completion: Invite 2 participants that enjoyed the task to share their positive experience with the group.

e12.title: Altruism
e12.objective: Provide altruism assignment instructions for next session.
steps: Introduce participants to the concept of altruism: doing good for others without expecting anything in return. Give examples of altruistic behaviours (fetching water for someone, carry weight, cheer someone up, accompany someone sick to go to the doctor, donating something yours to someone who needs it most, etc).

Ask participants to consider doing an altruistic task between this session and the next one. Be careful with the tone of voice to not “order” them to do it. Emphasize they should only do it if they feel like doing it, it is a choice they made. Tell them it is ok if they don’t do it or if they choose not to (giving traumatised individuals options is empowering).

e12b.title: Altruism Task Review
e12b.objective: To empower participants who conducted altruism tasks and promote restoration of trust in others among those who listen to task reviews
steps: Make sure people do not start leaving the group before others volunteer to share their experience.

Remind the group about the task assigned and ask if anyone who completed the task would like to share their experience. Important: encourage everyone in the group to clap after each experience is shared.
Write down in a piece of paper/ booklet the altruism tasks completed by the group for record keeping.

e13.title: Kind Voice
e13.objective: Help your participants develop a positive voice to diminish the impact of past negative authoritative messages and relationships
steps: Give participants examples of external negative voices, (someone saying, “You will never be good at this”).
Give participants examples of negative self-talk, (saying to yourself, “I will never be good at this”).
Now ask participants to think of positive compliments someone said to them, or positive things they say to themselves when they are alone.
Invite participants to share the positive statements.
Invite participants to use a kind voice to say a compliment to someone else in the group.
Ask participants to remain mindful for the rest of the day of what kind of voice they speak to themselves and others.

e14.title: Five Things
e14.objective: The goal of this exercise is to help participants advance their skills of mindfulness (focusing in the present moment)
steps: Ask your group to look around and together in loud voice identify 5 things they can SEE in this surrounding.
Ask your group to look around and together in loud voice identify 4 things they can TOUCH in this surrounding.
Ask your group to look around and together in loud voice identify 3 things they can HEAR in this surrounding.
Ask your group to look around and together in loud voice identify 2 things they can SMELL in this surrounding.
Ask your group to look around and together in loud voice identify 1 thing they can TASTE in this surrounding.

e15.title: My People
steps: Ask participants to think of 3 people in their lives they can rely on in good and bad times. If they cannot think of 3 persons it can be 2 or 1. If they cannot think of anyone, ask them to imagine what someone they can trust are like.
Ask them to think of this person(s) qualities that make them feel good and protected.

Introduce the thought that it is ok to trust and rely people for different situations in life. Some we trust with personal thoughts and feelings, others we rely on to feel good, others to enjoy social activities. All relationships are important for different reasons.

Group participation
Ask one person who feel comfortable to share who they rely on to talk about their emotions, failures and fears, someone they can keep secrets with and not judge them when they do wrong.

Group participation
Ask one person who feel comfortable to share who they rely on to make them very joyful and brings positive feelings whenever they are in their presence.

Group participation
Ask one person who feel comfortable to share who they rely on to go out and engage in social activities, but not necessarily share deep emotional conversations with.

e16.title: Grounding
e16.objective: The goal of this exercise is to assist participants to improve awareness of their bodies and feel good in it.
steps: Ask participants to find a comfortable position and close their eyes. When they are ready, ask them to take a deep breath and stretch both arms in the air.
Still with eyes closed, ask participants to bring attention to FEET and TOES, and notice how it feels in contact with the ground.
Ask participants to bring attention to LEFT AND RIGHT LEGS. Ask them to notice if the legs feel secure or shaking, and visualise the force of gravity keeping them grounded.
Ask participants to bring attention to STOMACH area and feel a connection between stomach and feet on the ground.
Ask participants to feel their full bodies connected, and notice the weight of their bodies where they are sitting, how heavy does it feel?
Ask participants to take a deep slow breath and slowly open their eyes.

e17.title: The Nurturer
e17.objective: Enhance self-esteem and sense of connectedness and belonging by helping participants identify people in their lives who trust and rely on them as a support system
steps: Remind participants that in the last session, they were asked to identify people they rely on for emotional intimacy, joy, and social activities.
Tell participants today we will do the reverse: think of 3 people that counts on them to play those roles.
In a moment of silence, ask participants to think about people who rely on them for support. If they cannot think of anyone, it is ok.
e17.completion: Invite two participants that feel comfortable to share how important they are for other people.

e18.title: Self Reflection
e18.objective: The goal of this exercise is to improve mindful self-awareness to enhance self-esteem
steps: Ask participants to think about 3 positive facts about themselves. It can be a compliment they received, a skill they are good at, an achievement, personality, how they handled a difficult situation. For those who cannot think of anything positive, remind them that their choice to come to this group shows is a powerful self-care initiative.

Group participation
Invite anyone willing to share their positive facts about themselves.

Group participation
Invite group members to share a positive quality someone else in the group.

e19.title: Purpose
e19.objective: Increase resilience in participants by helping them identify purposeful roles in society, self-worth, community building, future orientation, and personal abilities
steps:
Explain to participants the importance for our wellbeing to have a purpose in life, and that it is common to lose purpose when life becomes difficult

Give examples: raising children, leading a community, belonging to one, protecting loved ones, being a healer or doctor, teacher, dancer, musician, cook, farmer, politician, advocate for important causes, etc.
In a moment of silence, ask participants to think of a purpose in life they have now, or one they could embrace if they do not have one at the moment.
Ask participants to remain and silence and think of how their purpose can have a positive impact in the life of those around them.
e19.completion: Invite two participants that feel comfortable to share their purpose in life and how it can impact others positively.

e20.title: Meaning Making
e20.objective: The goal of this exercise is to help participants become aware of resources to cope with negative emotions and stress
steps: Talk to participants about the importance of exercising the ability of attributing a good meaning to bad experiences to overcome difficult times. Give examples of hardships and how meaning making assisted in the process of recovery.

Group participation
Ask if anyone would like to share an example of a positive meaning attributed to a difficult experience and how it helped them overcome. Gently change topics if participant focuses on talking about the bad experience. Focus on the positive meaning making only to avoid triggers.

e21.title: Team Gesture
e21.objective: To help participants increase concern for others, inspire good behaviour to create/restore social connections. Engage brain areas related to planning and decision making.
steps: Ask everyone in the group to think of a kind gesture they could do for their community, if they were given all resources needed. Tell them it is just an imagination exercise and they do not have to execute the plan in real life, so they can suggest anything even if they are unable to do it.

Group participation
Ask someone who feels comfortable to share their idea their idea with the group.

Group participation
Now, encourage group discussion and ask them to create a strategy to implement the idea together. Who would be responsible for which task?! What tools and roles are needed?! How can each person help to make the plan succeed and benefit all community?

e22.title: Resources
steps: Ask participants to think of resources you have in your life that gives you strength in difficult times. What made them feel better when last time they were sad or depressed? Give them time to think about it.

Group participation
Invite participants to name at least 3 resources that are external (Don’t mention the responses you want to hear unless no one mentions: External resources can be family, friends, hobbies, TV, entertainment, music, work, etc).

Group participation
Invite participants to name at least 3 resources that are internal – what within themselves makes them feel stronger? (Don’t mention the responses you want to hear unless no one mentions: Internal resources can be wisdom, intuition, spirituality, prayer, feeling joy, contentment, desire to help others, etc).

e23.title: Kind Community
e23.objective: Promote a sense of safety and wellbeing while acknowledging the presence of community
steps: Ask participants to close their eyes, take a few deep breaths, and notice how their bodies feel by following the air travel inside their bodies.
When they are calm and relaxed, while keeping their eyes closed, ask them to acknowledge and sense the presence of the participants in this group, appreciating a sense of belonging and togetherness.
Guide them to notice in their bodies how good it feels when feeling that they belong in this group and community.
Bring their attention back to their bodies and breath.
Count until 5 and ask them to slowly open their eyes.

e24.title: 10 Great Things
e24.objective: The goal of this exercise is to increase positive feelings and inspire mindful appreciation and focus on good events. Do not make religious associations (blessings), it is only ok if the participant make it.
steps: Ask participants to take a moment to think of 5 great things that happened to them and changed their lives for better.  (Something someone did, a gift received, a person met, a trip, job, school, spiritual experience, a book read, a child being born, or any other thing that makes them feel good and happy to be alive).

Group participation
Invite members to choose only 1 of the 5 great things to share with the group.

Ask participants to take a moment to think of 5 great things that happen more often, but sometimes we don’t noticed for being small everyday things.  (It could be the smell of flowers, the laughter of children, eating their favourite food, a sunny day, anything else that makes them smile).

Group participation
Invite members to choose only 1 of the 5 great everyday things to share with the group.
